section.name: What is Velocity?
section.p: Velocity is a Java-based template engine. It permits anyone to use a simple yet powerful template language to reference objects defined in Java code.

Velocity is written in 100% pure Java and can be easily embedded into your own applications. It also provides easy integration into web applications through a servlet and tasks for using Velocity from Apache Ant.

subsection.name: Web based applications
subsection.p: When Velocity is used for web development, Web designers can work in parallel with Java programmers to develop web sites according to the Model-View-Controller (MVC) model, meaning that web page designers can focus solely on creating a site that looks good, and programmers can focus solely on writing top-notch code. Velocity separates Java code from the web pages, making the web site more maintainable over its lifespan and providing a viable alternative to Java Server Pages (JSPs) or PHP.

subsection.name: Template based code and report generation
subsection.p: Velocity's capabilities reach well beyond the realm of the web; for example, it can be used to generate SQL, PostScript and XML (see Anakia for more information on XML transformations) from templates. It can be used either as a standalone utility for generating source code and reports, or as an integrated component of other systems.

subsection.name: Framework Integration
subsection.p: A huge number of other projects have Velocity integration either natively or through 3rd party add-ons. Some examples are:

ul.li: Turbine uses Velocity as its main view layer.
Struts offers Velocity integration through a Velocity subproject called Velocity Tools .
Spring Framework supports Velocity through its VelocityConfigurer and VelocityViewResolver.

section.name: How do I get started
section.p: The Velocity engine subproject contains the documentation to get started using Velocity and embedding Velocity into your own applications. Please select either a released version to get started.

section.name: Velocity subprojects
section.p: Velocity currently consists of three subprojects:

ul.li: Velocity Engine. This is the actual templating engine which does all the work. This subproject contains also the task definitions for using Velocity from Apache Ant.

Velocity Tools. This subproject contains tools and other useful infrastructure to build web- and non-web application using Velocity. You will find e.g. code for Struts integration or the standalone Velocity View Servlet here.

Velocity DVSL. DVSL (Declarative Velocity Style Language) is a tool modeled after XSLT and is intended for general XML transformations using the Velocity Template Language as the transformation language.

section.name: Where do I get nightly snapshots?
section.p:
Nightly snapshots of the source code for all subprojects can be found here.
They are meant to provide easy access to the project source code if you are located behind a firewall or don't want to deal with a subversion client and are created automatically from the Subversion repository.
As this is our live development workspace, there are no guarantees as to what you will find there, although we do our best to maintain a buildable source tree. If you are looking for the stable supported release, please use a released version.
If you are willing to risk getting dirty, we invite you to try the nightly snapshot to see the current state of affairs. (and help out!) Public Subversion access is also available.

section.name: How do I contribute, give feedback, fix bugs and so on?
section.p: The Velocity project appreciates any contributions, including documentation help, source code and feedback. Suggested changes should come in the form of source code and/or feedback.

ul.li: Report bugs, ask questions, and help new users on the Velocity mailing lists.
There's a list of issues waiting to be addressed in JIRA.
Our Wiki has a large collection of community written content. Add your own article or contribute to the FAQ!

Read-only access to the Subversion jakarta-velocity repository is available both
online and with a Subversion client.
